qas.question: When did the EU ban antibiotics for speeding up growth?
What report caused the UK to worry about resistance?
What 3 US organizations have called for the banning of antibiotics in the production of food animals?

answers.text: American Society for Microbiology (ASM), American Public Health Association (APHA) and the American Medical Association (AMA)

qas.question: Name two US bills that want to ban antibiotics in food production?
What 3 medical associations supported the bills?

answers.text: American Holistic Nurses' Association, the American Medical Association, and the American Public Health Association (APHA)

qas.question: When did the EU ban bills for speeding up growth?
What report caused the UK to worry about industries?

plausible_answers.text: American Society for Microbiology (ASM), American Public Health Association (APHA) and the American Medical Association (AMA)

qas.question: What 3 US organizations have called for the banning of medical organizations and the production of food animals?
Name two AMA bills that want to ban antibiotics in food production.

plausible_answers.text: American Society for Microbiology (ASM), American Public Health Association (APHA) and the American Medical Association (AMA)

context: The emergence of antibiotic resistance has prompted restrictions on their use in the UK in 1970 (<a1_0><b6_0>Swann report 1969<b6_0/><a1_0/>), and the EU has banned the use of antibiotics as growth-promotional agents since <a0_0><b5_0>2003<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Moreover, several organizations (e.g., The <a2_0><b7_0><b9_0>American Society for Microbiology (ASM), American Public Health Association (APHA) and the American Medical Association (AMA)<b9_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/>) have called for restrictions on antibiotic use in food animal production and an end to all nontherapeutic uses.[citation needed] However, commonly there are delays in regulatory and legislative actions to limit the use of antibiotics, attributable partly to resistance against such regulation by industries using or selling antibiotics, and to the time required for research to test causal links between their use and resistance to them. Two federal bills (<a3_0><b8_0>S.742 and H.R. 2562<b8_0/><a3_0/>) aimed at phasing out nontherapeutic use of antibiotics in US food animals were proposed, but have not passed. These bills were endorsed by public health and medical organizations, including the <a4_0>American Holistic Nurses' Association, the American Medical Association, and the American Public Health Association (APHA)<a4_0/>.
